case_name: U.P. State Electricity Board v. Official Liquidator of the Lower Ganges Jamuna Electricity Distributing Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1201 of 1967 filed.

In 1957 the Sixth Schedule of the Electricity Supply Act, 1948 was amended introducing a new clause VA which reads There shall be created a reserve to be called the Development Reserve to which shall be appropriated in respect of each accounting year a sum equal to the amount of income-tax and super-tax calculated at rates applicable during the assessment year for which the accounting year of the licensee is the previous year, on the amount, of development rebate to which the licensee is entitled for the accounting year under clause vi b of sub-section 2 of section 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

concepts.unlisted_label: Sixth Schedule Clause VA, Electricity (Supply) Act, 1948
concepts.unlisted_description: Requires creation of Development Reserve equal to tax on development rebate, available only for investment in electricity supply business, to be handed over on purchase or deducted if by Board.

anchor.surface_text: As already noticed under clause VA of the Sixth Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act, 1948, on the purchase of an undertaking the Development Reserve shall be handed over to the purchaser.

concepts.interpretation: Development Reserve to be handed over only if available; cannot hand over notional amount if converted to assets passed to purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-cl. 3 of clause VA of the Sixth Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act, 1948 the Development Reserve shall be available only for investment in the business of electricity supply of the undertaking.

concepts.interpretation: No prohibition on using reserve for permitted purpose; if used in business enhancing assets, no separate payment required.

anchor.surface_text: On the purchase of an Electricity Undertaking by the Electricity Board the market value of the Undertaking at the time of the purchase is payable under section 7A of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 and under sub-section 2 of that section the market value shall be deemed to be the value of all lands, buildings, works, materials and plant of the licensee, suitable to, and used by him, for the purpose of the undertaking but without any addition in respect of compulsory purchase or of goodwill or of any profits which may be or might have been made from the undertaking or of any similar consideration.

concepts.unlisted_description: Defines market value payable on purchase of undertaking by Board.

issues.text: Whether the Development Reserve must be handed over to the purchaser or deducted from the purchase price on purchase of the undertaking under clause VA of the Sixth Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act, 1948, even if it has been fully utilised for investment in the business of electricity supply of the undertaking and converted into assets enhancing the value of the undertaking transferred to the purchaser.

Though in the beginning there was a dispute about the actual amount in the Development Reserve it was finally agreed that the above sum was the compan

issues.text: Whether the language of clause VA of the Sixth Schedule differs from that in clauses II, III and IV so as to require handing over of the Development Reserve to the purchaser irrespective of its utilisation in the creation of tangible assets passed to the purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: We are number impressed by the argument on behalf of the appellant Board that companypared to the language used in clauses II, III and IV which deal with the Tariffs and Dividends Control Reserve and the Contingencies Reserve, the language in clause VA regarding the Development Reserve is different and,

issues.text: Whether section 70 of the Electricity Supply Act, 1948 provides guidance for interpreting clause VA of the Sixth Schedule to require payment of the Development Reserve separately.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does section 70 of the 1948 Act give us any guide in interpreting the relevant provision of law which will lead to the companyclusion companytended for by the appellant

arguments.claim: The Development Reserve had been used in adding to the assets of the Electricity Undertaking and therefore that amount could not be paid separately.

anchor.surface_text: The Official Liquidator contended that the Development Reserve had been used in adding to the assets of the Electricity Undertaking and, therefore, that amount could not be paid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; reserve available only for investment in business, fully utilized therein, no cash left; Board benefited via enhanced assets.

arguments.claim: Language in clause VA differs from clauses II, III, IV regarding other reserves, requiring Development Reserve to be handed over irrespective of utilization.

anchor.surface_text: We are not impressed by the argument on behalf of the appellant Board that compared to the language used in clauses II, III and IV which deal with the Tariffs and Dividends Control Reserve

arguments.court_reasoning: Not impressed; Division Bench dealt in detail, agree; no such distinction leading to payment even if used in assets passed to purchaser.

arguments.claim: Development Reserve available only for investment in electricity supply business; used for that purpose with no misuse alleged; fully converted to assets enhancing undertaking value, benefiting Board.

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-cl. 3 of clause VA of the Sixth Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act, 1948 the Development Reserve shall be available only for investment in the business of electricity supply

arguments.claim: Development Reserve can only be handed over if available; notional amount cannot; has been converted into assets passed to Board, who already benefited; demanding cash would mean paying twice.

anchor.surface_text: The Development Reserve can be handed over to the purchaser only if it is, available. A notional amount cannot be handed over. The Development Reserve has been converted into other

arguments.claim: No distinction in clause VA from other clauses warranting separate payment of Development Reserve where utilized in assets passed to purchaser.

arguments.claim: Section 70 of 1948 Act does not guide interpretation leading to appellant's contended conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does section 70 of the 1948 Act give us any guide in interpreting the relevant provision of law which will lead to the conclusion contended for by the appellant

arguments.claim: Clause VA language differs from earlier clauses as inserted later in 1957, but creates no interpretative difficulty.

anchor.surface_text: The provision regarding Development Reserve came into existence only in 1957 when the new clause VA was inserted in the Sixth Schedule by Act 101 of 1956 with effect from. 1-4-1957.

arguments.claim: Official Liquidator cannot be directed to pay amount to Board as no cash left in Development Reserve after utilization in business.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore,find ourselves in agreement with the learned Judges of the High Court that as the Development Reserve is available for investment in the business-of electricity supply of the

holdings.text: The Official Liquidator cannot be directed to pay any amount to the appellant Board as representing the Development Reserve since it is available only for investment in the business of electricity supply, the entire sum has been utilized therein, and no amount is left in cash.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore,find ourselves in agreement with the learned Judges of the High Court that as the Development Reserve is available for investment in the business-of electricity supply of the undertaking and the entire sum therein has been utilized by investment in such business and there is noamount left in cash in the Development Reserve the Official Liquidator cannot be directed to pay any amount to the appellant Board as representing the Development Reserve.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies clause VA sub-cl. 3 permitting investment in business; facts show full utilization without misuse, assets transferred, no cash available; notional payment unjust.

holdings.text: A notional amount representing the Development Reserve cannot be handed over to the purchaser; it can only be handed over if available, and here it has been converted into other assets passed to the Board.

anchor.surface_text: The Development Reserve can be handed over to the purchaser only if it is, available. A notional amount cannot be handed over. The Development Reserve has been converted into other assets which have passed on to the appellant Board.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of clause VA sub-cl. 4 requiring handover of the reserve if available; factual finding of conversion to assets means Board already benefited, double payment inequitable.

holdings.text: There is no distinction in clause VA from clauses II, III, IV warranting payment of the Development Reserve even if used in creation of tangible assets passed to purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: We can see no such distinction which will lead to the conclusion that the accumulated Development Reserve should be paid over to the purchaser even where it has already been used up in the creation of tangible assets which have passed on to the purchaser.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects textual distinction argument; agrees with Division Bench analysis; harmonious interpretation across clauses.

holdings.text: Section 70 of the Electricity Supply Act, 1948 does not provide any guide for interpreting clause VA to require separate payment of the Development Reserve.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does section 70 of the 1948 Act give us any guide in interpreting the relevant provision of law which will lead to the conclusion contended for by the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct assessment: section offers no interpretive aid for appellant's position on Development Reserve.

holdings.text: The decision of the courts below overruling the Board's contention that Rs. 1,45,422 from Development Reserve be handed over or deducted was right.

anchor.surface_text: This contention having been overruled by the Courts below this appeal has been filed. It appears to us that the decision of the Courts below was right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower courts based on clause VA interpretation and facts of utilization in permitted investments enhancing transferred assets.
